Award.AwardTitle: The Development of Quantitative Competencies in Preschool Children

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a five-year longitudinal study designed to examine early foundations of formal mathematical learning. Approximately, 250 children in Missouri will be assessed twice per year from preschool through first grade. Specific competencies to be measured include number, number relations, and number operations as well as language, executive function, attention, IQ, and social behavior. Symbolic and non-symbolic quantitative skills are considered. Data collected on this project will link to the Missouri Longitudinal Study of Mathematical Development and Disability.

Competence in arithmetic and basic algebra has been shown to be strongly related to employability, wages, and on-the-job productivity. Children who begin school behind their peers in mathematical competencies tend to stay behind throughout their schooling. The goal of this project is to conduct a longitudinal study with at-risk 3 year olds to improve the field?s understanding of the development of early numeracy development in young children and its relation to school mathematics outcomes. The project hopes to shed light on how domain general executive functions, nonverbal intelligence, and verbal intelligence interact with quantitative knowledge to lead to math achievement at the end of kindergarten.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As many as 1 out of 4 American adults are functionally innumerate. These adults do not have the quantitative competencies needed to qualify for many jobs in today’s economy or deal with now routine day-to-day quantitative tasks, such as understanding mortgages or medical treatment options. As noted in the final report of the President’s National Mathematics Advisory Panel (NMAP):

[The] concerns of national policy relating to mathematics education go far beyond those in our society who will become scientists or engineers. The national workforce of future years will surely have to handle quantitative concepts more fully and more deftly than at present. So will the citizens and policy leaders who deal with the public interest in positions of civic leadership. Sound education in mathematics across the population is a national interest. (NMAP 2008, pp. xi-xii).

In other words, poor mathematical competencies undermine the economic and general wellbeing of individuals, as well as the communities and nations in which they reside. It is now known that children who start school behind in mathematics tend to stay behind throughout their school years and into adulthood. In our previous studies, we identified the school entry (beginning of 1st grade) number knowledge (e.g., understanding that 6 = 5+1 = 4+2 = 3+3, or that 72 > 58) that predicts employment-relevant mathematical competencies in adolescence, independent of parental background, race, sex, or cognitive ability. 

With this project, we stepped back three years and focused on the early quantitative abilities that might be the foundation for children’s school entry number knowledge. We assessed children throughout two years of preschool, in kindergarten, and in 1st grade. By following these children for 4 years and assessing many different quantitative abilities, we were able to isolate the core conceptual knowledge that is the foundation for their quantitative learning before the start 1st grade. This core knowledge is called the cardinality principle, and represents children’s understanding of the quantities (cardinal value) represented by number words and the insight and each successive number word is one more than the word before it (e.g., ‘five’ is one more than ‘four’). Once children understand this principle, their learning of other aspects of number (e.g., learning the meaning of numerals, ‘1, 2, 3…’) accelerates, whether the learning occurs informally (e.g., with parents) or formally (e.g., in preschool). Moreover, we discovered that children who do not have this insight by the time they are four-years-old are at risk for starting 1st grade with a poor understanding of the number knowledge that predicts long-term growth in mathematical competencies. These findings are independent of parental education, reading skills, or cognitive ability. The results have very clear and substantive implications for the development of targeted interventions for preschool children at risk for long term difficulties with mathematics.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/06/2017
Modified by: David C Geary
